S/he, by Catherine Bruton

â€œThe new kid at school is not like anyone Kat has met before. Raven is â€˜gender-fluidâ€™. Not a boy. Or a girl. But kind of both - sometimes, sort of. At first the class are fascinated, intrigued. â€œToday will change Adam Thornâ€™s life. Between his religious family, unpleasant boss and his ex-boyfriend, the bindings of his world are coming undone. And way across town, a ghost has risen from the lake. Is there time for Adam to find his release?â€

â€œBut when one of Montyâ€™s reckless decisions turns their trip abroad into a harrowing manhunt, it calls into question everything he knows, including his relationship with the boy he adores.â€

Non-fiction

Trans Mission: my quest for a beard, by Alex Bertie

â€œBeing a teenager is difficult enough, but having to go through puberty whilst realising youâ€™re in the wrong body means dealing with a whole new set of problems: bullying, self-doubt and in some cases facing a physical and medical transition.

â€œAlex is an ordinary teenager: he likes pugs, donuts, retro video games and he sleeps with his socks on. Heâ€™s also transgender, and was born female. Heâ€™s been living as a male for the past few years and he has recently started his physical transition. Beyond Magenta: transgender teens speak out, by Susan Kuklin

â€œAuthor and photographer Susan Kuklin met and interviewed six transgender or gender-neutral young adults and used her considerable skills to represent them thoughtfully and respectfully before, during, and after their personal acknowledgment of gender identity. Portraits, family photographs and candid images grace the pages, augmenting the emotional and physical journey each youth has taken.â€

This Book is Gay, by Juno Dawson

â€œFormer PSHCE teacher and acclaimed YA author Juno Dawson, formerly known as James Dawson, gives an uncensored look at sexual orientation and gender identity.
